sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá mise i mo chónaí tamall fada amach, ar imeall na cathrach.
sentence.translation: I live a long way away, on the edge of the city.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An maith leat an ceantar?
sentence.translation: Do you like the area?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Is ann a rugadh agus a tógadh mé.
sentence.translation: It's where I was born and raised.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá aithne agat ar gach éinne, mar sin?
sentence.translation: You know everybody, then?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Ach tá sé go deas casadh ar dhaoine nua freisin.
sentence.translation: But it's nice to meet new people, too.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Céard is ainm duit arís?
sentence.translation: What is your name again?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cén seoladh atá agat?
sentence.translation: What is your address?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An raibh tú riamh i gCarna?
sentence.translation: Have you ever been to Carna?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá Carna go hálainn.
sentence.translation: Carna [a place in County Galway] is nice.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá mise i mo chónaí díreach in aice na farraige.
sentence.translation: I live right beside the sea.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An bhfuil garáiste i gCarna?
sentence.translation: Is there a garage in Carna?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Bhuel, tabhair an carr seo ann amárach.
sentence.translation: Well, take the car there tomorrow.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá an solas sin briste.
sentence.translation: That light is broken.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Inis dom faoin sráidbhaile. An bhfuil áiseanna maithe ann?
sentence.translation: Tell me about the village. Are there good amenities there?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá áiseanna den chéad scoth ann. Tá siopaí maithe ann, oifig an phoist, scoileanna, banc, agus linn snámha.
sentence.translation: There are excellent facilities there. There are good shops there, a post office, schools, a bank and a swimming pool.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An bhfuil mórán le déanamh san oíche ann?
sentence.translation: Is there much to do there at night?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá cúpla teach tábhairne ann, agus bíonn seisiúin cheoil ar siúl ag an deireadh seachtaine.
sentence.translation: There are a couple of pubs there, and there are often music sessions on at the weekend.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá mé i mo chónaí faoin tuath.
sentence.translation: I live in the country.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá sí ina cónaí i mbruachbhaile darb ainm An Tamhlacht.
sentence.translation: She lives in a suburb called Tallagh.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Táimid inár gcónaí ar imeall na cathrach.
sentence.translation: We live on the edge of the city.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá siad ina gcónaí in aice leis an gcósta.
sentence.translation: They live near the coast.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Is baile beag é.
sentence.translation: It's a small town.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Is ceantar mór turasóireachta é.
sentence.translation: It's a big tourist area.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cé mhéad deartháir agus deirfiúr atá agat?
sentence.translation: How many brothers and sisters do you have?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá deartháir amháin agam.
sentence.translation: I have one brother.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Níl aon deirfiúr agam.
sentence.translation: I have no sisters.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An bhfuil tú féin agus do dheartháir an-mhór le chéile?
sentence.translation: Are you and your brother very close?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá sé pósta anois.
sentence.translation: He is married now.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá a bhean ag súil le páiste i gceann cúpla mí.
sentence.translation: His wife is expecting a child in a couple of months.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Beidh tú i d'aintín, mar sin.
sentence.translation: You will be an aunt, then.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Táim ag súil go mór leis.
sentence.translation: I am looking forward to it very much.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cá mhéad duine agaibh a bhí ann?
sentence.translation: How may of you were there?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Deichniúr againn ar fad a bhí ann.
sentence.translation: All ten of us were there.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá an deichniúr acu fós beo, buíochas le Dia.
sentence.translation: The ten of them are still alive, thank God.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Fan go bhfeice mé - seisear buachaillí agus ceathrar cailíní. An bhfuil an ceart agam?
sentence.translation: [Looking at a family photo:] Let me see - six boys and four girls. Am I right?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An in Éirinn atá siad ina gcónaí?
sentence.translation: Are they living in Ireland?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá triúr i Meiriceá, beirt san Astráil, beirt eile i Sasana, agus duine eile san Afraic Theas.
sentence.translation: Three are in America, two in Australia, another two in England and one in South Africa.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Níl sa bhaile anois ach mé féin agus mo dheartháir Pádraig.
sentence.translation: The only people at home now are myself and my brother Pádraig.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá fáilte romhaibh ar ais. Ar an chlár inniu tá mé ag caint le Aoife Ní Loideáin.
sentence.translation: Welcome back. On the programme today I am talking to Aoife Ní Loideáin.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An bhfuil deartháir nó deirfiúr ar bith agat?
sentence.translation: Do you have any brothers or sisters at all?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cé acu duine agaibh is sine, tusa nó Siobhán?
sentence.translation: Which of you is older, you or Siobhán?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Is í Siobhán is sine.
sentence.translation: Siobhán is the oldest.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá sí trí bliana níos sine ná mise.
sentence.translation: She is three years older than me.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An réitíonn tú go maith léi?
sentence.translation: Do you get on well with her?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Réitím go maith léi, den chuid is mó.
sentence.translation: I get on well with her, for the most part.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá mise níos sine ná Bríd.
sentence.translation: I am older than Bríd.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá Peadar níos óige ná Darren.
sentence.translation: Peadar is younger than Darren.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Is é Julian an duine is sine sa chlann.
sentence.translation: Julian is the oldest in the family.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Is í Eithne an duine is óige sa chlann.
sentence.translation: Eithne is the youngest in the family.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Is mise an dara duine is óige.
sentence.translation: I am the second youngest.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Is mise an tríú duine is sine.
sentence.translation: I am the third oldest.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Agus an tusa an duine is sine?
sentence.translation: And are you the oldest?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Mise chomh maith!
sentence.translation: Me too!

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cé acu duine agaibh is sine?
sentence.translation: Which one of you is older?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá sise pósta agus triúr clainne aici.
sentence.translation: She is married with three children.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá sise pósta chomh maith.
sentence.translation: She is married as well.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Sin Úna, sin Niamh. Ansin Muiris: tá seisean i lár báire. Ansin Fiona; agus mise ar deireadh.
sentence.translation: [Looking at a family photo:] That's Úna, that's Niamh. Then Muiris, he is in the middle. Then Fiona; and myself at the end.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: In Chicago atá sí leis na blianta fada.
sentence.translation: She's been in Chicago for years and years.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Agus sin iad Seán agus Tomás - cúpla iadsan.
sentence.translation: And those are Seán and Tomás - they're twins.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: San Afraic Theas atá Tomás - ar na misin.
sentence.translation: Tomás in South Africa - on the missions.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Agus cé hí seo?
sentence.translation: And who is this? [assuming it's a woman]

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cailleadh a fear céile go tobann anuraidh, beannacht Dé leis.
sentence.translation: Her husband died suddenly last year, God have mercy on him.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Bhí sibh chomh cosúil lena chéile nuair a bhí sibh beag!
sentence.translation: You were so alike when you were little!

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cad é faoi do thuismitheoirí? An réitíonn tú go maith leo siúd?
sentence.translation: What about your parents? Do you get on well with them?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá mo thuismitheoirí scartha.
sentence.translation: My parents are separated.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Réitím níos fearr le m'athair ná le mo mháthair.
sentence.translation: I get on better with my father than with my mother.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An le do mháthair atá tú i do chónaí?
sentence.translation: Are you living with your mother?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Feicim m'athair go minic.
sentence.translation: I see my father often.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Triúr agaibh atá sa teach, mar sin.
sentence.translation: There are three of you in the house, then.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá aintín le mo mháthair ina cónaí linn chomh maith.
sentence.translation: My mother's aunt is living with us as well.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Bíonn muid ag troid seasta!
sentence.translation: We are constantly fighting!

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cén aois atá tú?
sentence.translation: What age are you?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cogar, cad atá ar siúl agat anocht?
sentence.translation: Listen, what are you doing tonight?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Ar mhaith leat teacht le haghaidh dinnéir liom?
sentence.translation: Would you like to come to dinner with me tonight?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá áit nua Iodálach oscailte i lár na cathrach.
sentence.translation: There's a new Italian place open in the city centre.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Is breá liom bia Iodálach!
sentence.translation: I love Italian food!

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cuirfidh mé bord in áirithe.
sentence.translation: I'll book a table.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Lá maith anois agat.
sentence.translation: Good day to you now. [to somebody who is leaving]

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cogar, an bhfuil tú saor anocht?
sentence.translation: Listen, are you free tonight?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá ceolchoirm iontach ar siúl i nGaillimh anocht.
sentence.translation: There's a brilliant concert on in Galway tonight.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá dhá thicéad agam.
sentence.translation: I've got two tickets.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá brón orm ach tá mé ag obair anocht.
sentence.translation: I'm sorry but I'm working tonight.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Bail ó Dhia ar an obair.
sentence.translation: God bless the work.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Go mba hé duit.
sentence.translation: Same to you. [response to a well-wish]

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cogar, an mbeidh tú ag mo chóisir?
sentence.translation: Listen, will you be at my party?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cén uair a bheidh an chóisir ar siúl?
sentence.translation: When is the party taking place?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Beidh sé ar siúl oíche Aoine, thiar san óstán.
sentence.translation: It's on Friday night, over in the hotel.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Nach bhfuair tú an cuireadh?
sentence.translation: Did you not get the invitation?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cé eile a beidh ann?
sentence.translation: Who else will be there?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Beidh muintir an bhaile uilig ann.
sentence.translation: All the people of the town will be there.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An mbeidh tú féin ann?
sentence.translation: Will you be there yourself?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá mé faoi bhrú an-mhór faoi láthair.
sentence.translation: I'm under a lot of pressure at the moment.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Níl a fhios agam.
sentence.translation: I don't know.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Is breá liom dul chuig ceolchoirmeacha.
sentence.translation: I love going to concerts.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Ba bhreá liom pionta anois.
sentence.translation: I'd love a pint now.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Ar mhaith leat teacht chuig mo chóisir?
sentence.translation: Would you like to come to my party?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Ba bhreá liom, ach beidh mé ag obair déanach.
sentence.translation: I'd love to but I'll be working late.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Caithfidh mé éirí go moch ar maidin.
sentence.translation: I have to get up early in the morning.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Beidh mé ag bualadh le roinnt cairde.
sentence.translation: I'll be meeting some friends.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá mé an-tuirseach.
sentence.translation: I am very tired.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Cén t-am é?
sentence.translation: What time is it?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá sé beagnach a naoi a chlog.
sentence.translation: It's almost nine o'clock.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá an-bhrón orm.
sentence.translation: I'm very sorry.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Bhí an trácht an-trom.
sentence.translation: The traffic was very heavy.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Bhí faitíos orm go raibh tú imithe amú!
sentence.translation: I was afraid you'd got lost!

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Bhí mé ag fanacht uair an chloig ar thacsaí.
sentence.translation: I was waiting for an hour for a taxi.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An bhfuil Aoife thart?
sentence.translation: Is Aoife around?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Mise atá ag obair anocht.
sentence.translation: I'm the one working tonight.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Shíl mé go raibh Aoife ag obair anocht.
sentence.translation: I thought Aoife was working tonight.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Tá sí ag dul chuig scannán.
sentence.translation: She's going to a film.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: An léi féin atá sí ag dul?
sentence.translation: Is she going on her own?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Scannán Francach atá ann, sílim.
sentence.translation: It's a French film, I think.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004
sentence.original: Bhí muid díreach ag caint fút.
sentence.translation: We were just talking about you.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Éamonn Ó Dónaill: Turas Teanga. RTÉ/Gill & Macmillan, 2004

sentence.translation: He travelled to Afganistan in 1999 and accepted Osama Bin Laden's personal request that he would organize air attacks on America.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: I 2000, thosaigh sé ag foghlaim eitilte i bhFlorida in éindí le Marbhan Al-Seithí agus Siad Deara.
sentence.translation: In 2000, he started learning to fly in Florida along with Marbhan Al-Seithí and Siad Deara.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: D'aimsigh sé duine eile a raibh taithí eitilte aige.
sentence.translation: He found another person who had flying experience.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: D'earcaigh sé 15 duine eile nach raibh mórán taithí acu ach i bhforéigean, agus chuadar faoi oiliúint.
sentence.translation: He recruited 15 other people with experience in little else than violence, and they started training.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: D'athraigh an dara ionsaí an tír láithreach.
sentence.translation: The second attack changed the country instantly.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Dúnadh aerfoirt uilig na tíre.
sentence.translation: All airports in the country were closed.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Tosaíodh ag aslonnú daoine as foirgnimh mhóra timpeall na tíre mar Túr Sears in Siceágo.
sentence.translation: People started being evacuated from tall buildings around the country such as Sears Tower in Chicago.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Agus níor stopadh den drochnuacht.
sentence.translation: And the bad news just kept on coming.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Bhí dhá fhoirgneamh an Lárionad Trádála trí thine.
sentence.translation: The two Trade Centre buildings were on fire.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ba chosúil go raibh níos mó eitleáin i spéartha Mheiriceá ag díriú ar spriocanna rúnda.
sentence.translation: It seemed that even more airplanes in American skies were targeting secret targets.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Agus scamaill dubha ag plúchadh amach as na túir i Nua-Eabhrac...
sentence.translation: While there were black clouds spewing from the towers in New York...

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Thosaigh tuairiscí ag teacht as Washington gur buaileadh an Pentagon.
sentence.translation: Reports started coming from Washington that the Pentagon had been hit.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ansin, nóiméad roimh a deich a chlog i Nua-Eabhrac tharla tubaiste nach raibh aon duine ag súil leis.
sentence.translation: Then, one minute before ten o'clock in New York, a disaster happened that nobody expected.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Thug túr theas an Lárionad Trádála uaidh.
sentence.translation: The Trade Centre's south tower let go [ie. started collapsing].

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Thart fán am ar thit túr eile an Lárionaid, bhí tuairiscí ag teacht isteach go raibh scairdeitleán ar lár i bPennsylvania.
sentence.translation: Around the time the other tower fell, reports were coming in of a jet missing in Pennsylvania.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: D'fhan an tír go léir faoi dhianslándáil ar feadh tamaill fhada ina dhiaidh sin.
sentence.translation: The whole country remained under intensive security for a long while after that.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Níor ceadaíodh ach correitilt sa tír go ceann seachtaine eile agus, ar ndóigh, ba bheag duine a bhí ag iarraidh eitilt ach oiread.
sentence.translation: For a whole week, flights were grounded in the country with only occasional exceptions and, of course, hardly anybody even wanted to fly.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ach níorbh shin é deireadh an scéil.
sentence.translation: But that was not the end of the story.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ba léir go raibh Stáit Aontaithe Mheiriceá ag pleanáil díoltais ollmhóir.
sentence.translation: Clearly, the United States of America were planning a big revenge.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ceithre seachtainí i ndiaidh na n-ionsaithe rinne fórsaí Mheiriceá ionruathar isteach san Afganastáin.
sentence.translation: Four weeks after the attacks American forces carried out an invasion i to Afghanistan.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Rinne siad ionruathar ar an Iaráic bliain go leith ina dhiaidh sin.
sentence.translation: They carried out an invasion on Iraq one and half year after that.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Tá trúpaí Mheiriceá sa dá thír sin fós, deich mbliana anonn.
sentence.translation: Both countries still have American troops in them, ten years later.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Cogadh a fhearadh ar an domhan mór, go háirithe ar thíortha a raibh ola acu.
sentence.translation: To wage war against the whole world, especially against countries that had oil.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Táthar ann a deir nach raibh in ionsaithe an 11ú Meán Fomhair ach leithscéal do Mheiriceá cogadh a fhearadh ar an domhan mór.
sentence.translation: Some people say the 11 September attacks were only an excuse for America to wage war against the whole world.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Go deimhin, tá ceisteanna go leor nár freagraíodh go fóill, go háirithe na cinn faoi fhoirgneamh a seacht.
sentence.translation: Indeed, there are still some unanswered questions, expecially those about building seven.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Thit an foirgneamh go talamh gan choinne i ndeireadh tráthnóna an lae úid.
sentence.translation: The building collapsed unexpectedly in late afternoon that day.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: I ndeireadh an lae, ámh, ní féidir na líomhaintí seo a chruthú.
sentence.translation: At the end of the day, though, these accusations cannot be proven.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Tá Osama Bin Laden agus tromlach a shaighdiúirí marbh anois.
sentence.translation: Osama Bin Laden and most of his soldiers are dead now.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: B'fhéidir go raibh a fhios ag Bin Laden sular mharaigh fórsaí speisialta Mheiriceá é gur athraigh sé an domhan as cuimse.
sentence.translation: Maybe Bin Laden knew before he was killed by American special forces that he had changed the world utterly.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ar mo bhealach ar ais as Éirinn an mhí seo caite, rinneadh scrúdú iomlán ar mo reitine agus ar mo mhéarlorga.
sentence.translation: On my way back from Ireland last month, I had to undergo a close examination of my retina and my fingerprints.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Rinneadh scrúdú iomlán ar mo reitine agus ar mo mhéarlorga, mar a dhéantar le gach éinne nach saoránach Meiriceánach é ar a bhealach isteach sa tír.
sentence.translation: I had to undergo a close examination of my retina and my fingerprints, like every non-American citizen on his way into the country.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: B'éigean dom mo bhróga, mo chrios, agus gach píosa miotal a bhaint díom, maille le pé leachtanna agus taois a bhí agam.
sentence.translation: I had to remove my shoes, my belt and every piece of metal, as well as any liquids and pastes I had.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Rinneadh seo in Aerfort na Sionainne, áit a bhfeictear na mílte saighdiúirí Meiriceánacha gach lá anois ar a mbealach chun na hIaráice.
sentence.translation: This was done in Shannon Airport where you see thousands of American soldiers every day on their way to Iraq.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Táimid inár gcónaí i ndomhan nua anois, a bhuíochas do Bin Laden, Mohammed Atta, agus na scórtha eile nach bhfuil ann níos mó chun é a fheiceáil.
sentence.translation: We live in a new world now, thanks to Bin Laden, Mohammed Atta and scores of others who are not there anymore to see it.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ar éirigh leo?
sentence.translation: Did they succeed?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Anseo i Nua-Eabhrac bhí crith beag talún againn an tseachtain seo caite.
sentence.translation: Here in New York we had a small earthquake last week.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: B'é scéimhlitheoireacht an chéad rud a rith le daoine sular tháinig deimhniú gurbh iad cúinsí seismeacha ba chúis leis an rud.
sentence.translation: The first that people though of was terrorism, until it transpired that the thing [the earthquake] has seismic causes.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Go cinnte, bheadh Osama Bin Laden ag gáirí.
sentence.translation: Osama Bin Laden would certainly be laughing.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Tá idir fhíricí agus bhreithiúnas sa mhéid sin. Seasaim leo araon.
sentence.translation: There are both facts and judgement in what I have just said. I stand behind them both.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Nuair a tugadh mo rogha seomra dom san óstán, d'fhreagraíos go cúramach.
sentence.translation: When I was asked what kind of room I wanted in the hotel, I answered carefully.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Bhris meangadh gáire amach ar aghaidh an fháilteora.
sentence.translation: A smile broke out on the receptionist's face.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Thuig sí go maith gur iomaí iriseoir a tógadh amach as an óstán ar chláirín.
sentence.translation: She knew well that many journalists had been carried out of the hotel on a board [ie. dead].

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Suas liom go seomra 1026 ar bharr an tí.
sentence.translation: Up I went to room 1026 at the top of the house.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Tá fáinne eochrach an tseomra fós agam.
sentence.translation: I still have the room's keyring.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Meabhrú laethúil ó shin dom ar na huafáis a chonaiceamar.
sentence.translation: My daily reminder, since then, of the horrors we've seen.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Na huafáis a chonaiceamar, uafáis nach n-oireann focla dóibh.
sentence.translation: The horrors we've seen, horrors words can't describe.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Níorbh é Milosevic amháin faoi ndear gach coir in aghaidh na daonnachta a tharla tráth titim as a chéile don Iúgslaiv.
sentence.translation: Milosevic was not solely responsible for every crime against humanity that happened while Yugoslavia was falling apart.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Bhí iar-Impireacht Aontas na bPoblachtaí Sóivéadacha Sóisialacha ag saothrú an bháis.
sentence.translation: The former Empire of the USSR was dying.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Smionagar amháin a bhí fágtha.
sentence.translation: Only fragments were left.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: An bhfuil deireadh le hiriseoireacht an tsaoránaigh?
sentence.translation: Is citizen journalism finished?

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Traidhfil blianta ó shin, bhíothas ag caint ar bhreacadh ré úr do na meáin chumarsáide.
sentence.translation: A few years ago people were talking about the dawning of a new age for the media.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Bhí deiseanna úra cruthaithe ag dul chun cinn teicneolaíoch.
sentence.translation: Technological progress had created new opportunities.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Sháraigh sé cuid mhaith de na fadhbanna seachadta agus rochtana a bhíodh ina gcrá croí ag iriseoirí le fada.
sentence.translation: It overcame a lot of the distribution and access problems that had been bothering journalists for a long time.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: De bharr na bhforbairtí seo bhí bosca uirlisí cumarsáide ag an saoránach a thug deis dó feidhmiú mar iriseoir ar bhonn domhanda agus ar bheagán costais.
sentence.translation: Because of these developments, the citizen now had a toolbox that gave him the chance to function as a journalist, globally and at little cost.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Níor ghá gur thomhaltóirí nuachta iad an lucht léitheoireachta nó éisteachta a thuilleadh ach táirgeoirí a bheadh in inmhe a gcuid tuairiscí féin a bhailiú.
sentence.translation: Readers and listeners did not have to be consumers of news anymore but producers who were able to collect their own reports.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ní raibh aon ghá le heagarthóir a thuilleadh le do leagan féin de cheird na hiriseoireachta a chleachtadh.
sentence.translation: You didn't need an editor anymore to practise your own version of the journalistic trade.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Bhíodh raon fairsing ábhair faoi chaibidil iontu agus tuairimí á nochtadh faoi achan rud faoin spéir.
sentence.translation: They [ie. blogs] were dealing with a wide range of topics and giving opinions on everything under the sun.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ar ndóigh bhí cuid acu chomh leamh le bheith ag amharc ar mhúscán gorm ag fás ar phíosa aráin.
sentence.translation: Of course, some of them were as boring as watching blue mould growing on a piece of bread.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ó am go chéile, áfach, bhíodh seoid ghrinn tuairimíochta nó léirmheas géarchúiseach le fáil iontu.
sentence.translation: But from time to time you could find in them [ie. in blogs] a sharp opinionated treasure or a shrewd review.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Chuir said ábhar léitheoireachta ar fáil do phobal na Gaeilge.
sentence.translation: They gave the Irish-language community something to read.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ach tá na blaganna Gaeilge ar fiú iad a léamh tearc go maith.
sentence.translation: But the blogs that are worth reading are few and far between.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Díomaite de chorrbhlag fánach, is beag nuashonrú a dhéantar ar fhormhór na suíomhanna.
sentence.translation: Apart from the odd blog here and there, most of the sites are only rarely updated.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Liosta le háireamh a bhí iontu tráth den saol.
sentence.translation: They were a considerable list once [ie. there were a lot of them].

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ach tá cuma spíonta ar chuid mhór acu fán tráth seo.
sentence.translation: But many of them look tired now.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ciúnas na reilige a bhí le cluinstean ó na blagadóirí faoi...
sentence.translation: All you could hear the bloggers about... was deadly silence.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Bhí an cás ina phríomhscéal ag na meáin fhadbhunaithe ar feadh breis is seachtaine.
sentence.translation: The affair was main news in the established media for over a week.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Is beag sásamh a bhaintear as athchúrsáil a dhéanamh ar ábhar atá ar fáil in áiteanna eile cheana féin.
sentence.translation: People get little satisfaction from recycling stuff that is already available elsewhere.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Is beag aischothú a fuair scríbhneoirí áirithe ar a gcuid blaganna.
sentence.translation: Some writers got very little feedback on their blogs.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Níorbh fhiú an tairbhe an trioblóid, b'fhéidir.
sentence.translation: I guess it wasn't worth the hassle.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Tá cumhacht gan fhreagracht ag na meatacháin ar líne.
sentence.translation: Online, cowards have power without responsbility.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Sa chomhthéacs sin, b'fhéidir nárbh fhiú an trioblóid le bheith ag scríobh blag.
sentence.translation: In that context, maybe writing a blog just wasn't worth the trouble.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: An chúis is mó go bhfuil meath tagtha ar bhlaganna na Gaeilge ná...
sentence.translation: The biggest reason why Irish-language blogs have started declining is...

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Níl luach saothair ar bith le baint as.
sentence.translation: There's no way you'll get proper monetary reward for that.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ba mhinic fosta gur maslaí ó dhaoine le hainmneacha cleite a bhíodh mar thoradh ar na tuairimí a nocht blagadóirí.
sentence.translation: Also, what bloggers often got in response to their opinions was abuse from anonymous people.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Tugann scaoilteacht an idirlín ardán d'achan chineál cancráin a bheith ag caitheamh anuas ar dhaoine eile faoi sciath na ganfhiosaíochta.
sentence.translation: The relaxed atmosphere of the Internet gives a platform to every sort of cantankerous git to give out to other people under the protection of anonymity.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Thuigfeá d'éinne nach mbeadh ag iarraidh feannadh den chineál sin a tharraingt orthu féin.
sentence.translation: You would understand why someone does not want to undergo that kind of skin stripping [ie. extreme criticism].

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Is beag iriseoir gairmiúil atá ábalta a bheatha a bhaint i dtír leis an bhlagadóireacht.
sentence.translation: Hardly any professional journalist is able to make a career out of blogging.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Anuas ar sin, ní thig éalú ó ghnáthchúraimí an tsaoil a thiteann ar dhuine, ar nós airgead a thuilleamh nó clann a thógáil.
sentence.translation: In addition to that, you cannot escape from the ordinary responsiblities life throws at you such as making money or raising a family.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Is maith an coincheap é iriseoireacht an tsaoránaigh ach i ndeireadh ama caithfear na billí a íoc!
sentence.translation: Citizen journalism is a nice concept but, in the end, somebody has to pay the bills!

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Thiocfadh leat a mhaíomh ar ndóigh, go...
sentence.translation: You could of course claim that...

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Twitter, an toighis chumarsáide is mó atá i bhfaisean san am i láthair.
sentence.translation: Twitter, the choice means of communication in fashion right now.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Seans gur fearr a fhóireann seirbhís mhicreabhlagála dá chineál don duine gnóthach atá ag iarraidh tuairimí a nochtadh.
sentence.translation: A microblogging service of its kind [ie Twitter] is probably better suited to a busy person who wants to share his opinions.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Éilíonn gontacht na formáide (140 carachtar) nach dtéann an scríbhneoir chun fadála ina chuid smaointe.
sentence.translation: The brevity of the format (140 characters) forces the writer to avoid verbosity in his thoughts.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Níl i Twitter go bunúsach ach teachtaireachtaí téacs don idirlíon.
sentence.translation: Twitter is basically just text messages for the Internet.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ní bheifeá ag súil leis an doimhneacht chéanna tuairimíochta uathu is a bheadh ó phostálacha níba fhaide ar nós blag nó colún ar líne.
sentence.translation: You wouldn't expect the same opiniated depth from them as you would from longer posts such as blogs or online columns.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Eascraíonn an cheist:...
sentence.translation: This raises a question:...

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Amanna, tugann na meáin aird ar na cásanna sin, amanna eile ní thugann.
sentence.translation: Sometimes the media pay attention to those cases, other times they don't.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: D'fhág muid slán ag a chéile don oíche.
sentence.translation: We said goodbye to each other for the night.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: I seilbh an phobail atá an tseanbheairic anois.
sentence.translation: The old barracks are in public ownership now.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Is iomaí gnáthdhuine a bhfuil gunna ina sheilbh.
sentence.translation: Many ordinary people have a gun in their possession.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Tá na meáin chumarsáide i seilbh lucht an rachmais.
sentence.translation: The media are owned by the rich.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Tá an chuid is mó de ghnólachtaí na tíre i seilbh phríobháideach.
sentence.translation: Most of the country's businesses are in private ownership.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Níor stop na Naitsithe leis an bPolainn, agus níorbh fhada go raibh an Fhrainc ina seilbh acu chomh maith.
sentence.translation: The Nazis didn't stop with Poland and it wasn't long until they had France in their possession as well.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Gabhadh é agus gunna ina sheilbh aige.
sentence.translation: He was arrested with a gun in his possession.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Is fearr le vótóirí an té a bhíos i seilbh na cumhachta.
sentence.translation: Voters prefer candidates who already have power.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Bhí an t-imreoir i seilbh na liathróide.
sentence.translation: The player was in possession of the ball.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ghlac na Lochlannaigh seilbh ar Eabhrac sa bhliain 867.
sentence.translation: The Vikings took York in their possession in the year 867.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Ghlac sí seilbh ar an micreafón agus thosaigh sí ag canadh.
sentence.translation: She got hold of the microphone and started singing.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Chuir siad cogadh ar arm an rí chun seilbh a fháil ar an teampall.
sentence.translation: The waged war on the king's army to acquire the temple.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Níl a fhios agam beo cad a tharla.
sentence.translation: I have no idea what happened.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
sentence.original: Tá seanreilig i lár chathair Bhoston.

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/

sentence.sourceBlurb: Beo, http://www.beo.ie/
